pr_title: Add AccessControlContext to store client information for security purposes

timeline.bodyText: Should we just change this to take the Identity as the first argument ? That way this matches all the other functions and if you take a look at the callsite, it anyways gets the principal from the Identity
timeline.author: mayankgarg1990

replies.bodyText: Yeah i thought there might be a reason why we are not sending Identityjust for this one rpc (?).  I am okay to change it to take Identity as first arg.
replies.author: NikhilCollooru

timeline.bodyText: Given the way it is being set, do you feel that just calling it clientInformation might be a better option?
timeline.author: mayankgarg1990

replies.bodyText: This is slightly more than the clientInfo we use at other places and in future we might add other info as well. So i went with extraInfo.  I am okay with either.
replies.author: NikhilCollooru

timeline.message: Add AccessControlContext to store client information for security purposes

timeline.bodyText: just return Optional<String> that way the implementation can decide what to do if the value is not present.
timeline.author: mayankgarg1990
mayankgarg1990

timeline.message: Add AccessControlContext to store client information for security purposes

timeline.bodyText:
I would recommend to group together the parameters that are generic to every method:
e.g.:
checkCanCreateSchema(ConnectorTransactionHandle transactionHandle, ConnectorIdentity identity, AccessControlContext context, String schemaName)

It is much easier to read the interface as it is easier to figure out what parameters are important, and what are a boilerplate.
Intellij has an utility for changing method signatures. It allows to easily change the parameters order.
timeline.author: arhimondr

timeline.bodyText: The AccessControlContext is based on the values that are already stored in the Session. Thus introduces data duplication that is potentially a risk of going out of sync. It doesn't feel like this object should be stored here.
timeline.author: arhimondr

replies.bodyText: I wonder if we should simply create the AccessControlContext in the getAccessControlContext (and maybe rename the method to something like createAccessControlContext)
replies.author: arhimondr

replies.bodyText:
Wouldn't it be bad to create a new AccessControlContext object everytime we need it ?
Instead can we NOT have it as an input param to the Session object constructor but keep it as private variable in Session object and create/initialize it inside the constructor method ?
replies.author: NikhilCollooru

replies.bodyText:
Wouldn't it be bad to create a new AccessControlContext object everytime we need it ?

Creating an object is cheap. Especially if it is very likely to get in-lined as a result of escape analysis. Also there's not that many checks that are performed per query. Thus I would consider additional overhead of creating an object to be negligible. Also in many cases (for example at workers) no security checks are done. So the object is not going to be created altogether.

Instead can we NOT have it as an input param to the Session object constructor but keep it as private variable in Session object and create/initialize it inside the constructor method ?

Yeah, we can create it in the constructor based on the parameters. It will protect the Session object from being in an inconsistent state (e.g.: when queryId of the Session is different then queryId of the AccessControlContext)
replies.author: arhimondr

replies.bodyText: Sounds good. Will go ahead with the idea of having AccessControlContext  as private variable in Session and creating/initializing it as part of the Session constructor.
replies.author: NikhilCollooru
